summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence between defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the defense's request to review physical evidence and highly confidential images in the FBI's custody. The emails discuss scheduling, evidence inventories, and the logistics of accessing evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is the primary correspondent requesting access to evidence and asking procedural questions.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C., copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Attorney at Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review for Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case "US v. Maxwell - 20 Cr. 330 (AJN/MN)". The evidence being discussed was seized in relation to her case.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier. Evidence discussed was seized from his residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands during 2019 searches.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Properties
events.description: The FBI's New York Office executed search warrants and seized physical items from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands.

events.title: Discovery Production
events.description: The prosecution produced discovery to the defense, including search warrant returns listing items seized from Epstein's properties and an index of physical items from the FBI-Miami office.

events.title: Scheduled Call Regarding Evidence
events.description: A call was scheduled between defense counsel and the AUSA to discuss the defense's requests to view evidence and highly confidential materials.

events.title: Proposed Evidence Review Date
events.description: The AUSA indicated the FBI could provide a laptop containing highly confidential images for the defense to review on this date.

1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)

keyFacts: The defense for Ghislaine Maxwell was actively seeking to review physical evidence and 'highly confidential images' in the FBI's custody in March 2021.

The FBI had seized evidence from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands in 2019, but had not prepared a comprehensive inventory of all items at the time of this correspondence.
The prosecution had previously produced an index of physical evidence from the FBI-Miami office, but acknowledged it did not include everything seized by the FBI's New York Office.
Logistical issues, including the FBI team being out of the office, were causing delays in scheduling the defense's review of evidence.
The correspondence reveals the procedural challenges and coordination between the defense, prosecution, and FBI regarding evidence access in a high-profile case.
